metadata.title: Mesoporous high surface area NiO synthesized with soft templates: Remarkable for catalytic CH<ce:inf loc=post>4</ce:inf> deep oxidation

Table 6 Catalysts H2-TPR results H2 uptake (mmolg−1) H/Ni molar ratio Ni3+/Ni2+ molar ratio NiO-PEG 15.19 2.24 0.32 NiO-PEG-650 15.06 2.23 0.30 NiO-PEG-750 14.86 2.21 0.27 NiO-PEG-850 14.60 2.16 0.23 Editor's choice paper Mesoporous high surface area NiO synthesized with soft templates: Remarkable for catalytic CH4 deep oxidation Xianglan Xu Lin Li Fan Yu Honggen Peng Xiuzhong Fang Xiang Wang ⁎ College of Chemistry, Nanchang University, Nanchang, 330031, China College of Chemistry Nanchang University Nanchang 330031 China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Mesoporous NiO nano-sheet catalysts have been successfully synthesized by hydrothermal method with polyethylene glycol (NiO-PEG) and polyvinyl pyrrolidone (NiO-PVP) as soft templates. Compared with NiO catalysts prepared with direct calcination and precipitation methods, both NiO-PEG and NiO-PVP possess a large amount of intraparticle and interparticle mesopores with different sizes, thus resulting in catalysts with much higher surface areas. As a consequence, a larger quantity of more mobile active oxygen species have been formed in these two catalysts. It is believed that the mesoporous structure, high surface area and the presence of more mobile oxygen species are the major factors improving the activity of the catalysts for CH4 deep oxidation. The formation of too much Ni3+ cations, which is induced by the Ni2+ vacancies present in the NiO crystal matrix, is harmful to the activity. With the optimal tuning of the above factors, NiO-PEG displays the highest activity to the target reaction, which is even rival to 1wt.% Pd/Al2O3 catalyst. In addition, this catalyst exhibits excellent reaction stability in the presence or absence of water vapour, and certain physical and thermal stability for the reaction. Indeed, the information provided in this work may give people some inspiration to develop catalysts without using noble metals for air emission control reactions. Keywords NiO catalyst Nanosheet Mesoporous Ni2+ vacancies CH4 deep oxidation 1 Introduction Catalytic oxidation of CH4 is an efficient way to prevent it from polluting the air or to utilize it as a fuel. Supported noble metal catalysts, especially Pt and Pd, are still the most efficient for CH4 deep oxidation, which have been currently applied in emission control processes [1–3]. Because of the limited availability and high prices of noble metals, there are still strong incentives to develop base metal oxide catalysts with low cost [4]. Over the past decades, transition metal oxide catalysts, such as CuO, Co3O4, MnOx, CeO2 and their composite oxides, have been extensively studied [5]. NiO supported on various supports are generally adopted for hydrocarbon reforming [6,7], hydrogenation and dehydrogenation [8,9] and methanation [10], which display high activity for these reactions and have been industrialized for some processes. Although metallic Ni shows high activity for the activation and splitting of the potent CH bonds in the CH4 molecules [11], only a few publications have been profiled to use NiO-based catalysts for methane deep oxidation. For instance, supported NiO/ZrO2, NiO/CeO2 and NiO/YSZ were reported for CH4 combustion and exhibited certain activity [12,13]. Zhang et al., [14] found that the doping of Mn cations into NiO lattice to form solid solution lead to markedly enhanced activity for CH4 deep oxidation, which is much higher than that the individual oxides. In addition, NiO nanoparticle sheets were also reported to be active for CH4 combustion [15]. More recently, our work has demonstrated that an individual mesoporous NiO nano-sheet catalyst, that was easily prepared by the traditional precipitation method, exhibits very good activity for CH4 deep oxidation, which is competitive to 0.5wt.% Pd/Al2O3 catalyst under the same condition [16]. However, the surface area of this catalyst is only around 30m2 g−1, which might limit the activity of the catalyst and restrict its potential industrial applications, since CH4 deep oxidation could be diffusion controlled, especially at high conversions [17,18]. Moreover, it has been previously reported that the catalytic performance of pure NiO for oxidation reaction can be further improved by controlling its morphology. NiO nanorings [19] and nanoflower [20] are found to display very good activity for CO oxidation. Dai and co-workers have reported that NiO nanoflower [21], nanorods and nanocubes [22] are very active for toluene oxidation, due to the presence of morphology effect, larger surface area, the formation of more facile surface oxygen sites and better reducibility. Among these nanomaterials, porous NiO nanoflower has drawn much attention and been prepared by various methods, since it shows excellent performance in electrochemistry [23,24], water treatment [25], gas sensors [26], catalysis [20,21,27] and lithium batteries [28]. However, little attention has been paid to the catalytic behavior of NiO nanoflower for CH4 deep oxidation. Therefore, with the expectation to prepare mesoporous NiO possessing higher surface areas and special morphologies matching CH4 deep oxidation, thus further improving its activity and facilitating its industrial application, in this study, soft templates such as polyethylene glycol (PEG) and polyvinyl pyrrolidone (PVP) have been adopted to prepare NiO catalysts by using hydrothermal method. As a result, a NiO nanoflower catalyst prepared with a PEG template is found to be very active for the target reaction, which shows even rival activity to 1wt.% Pd/Al2O3 catalyst under the same condition and also displays potent water resistance. With various characterization techniques, the structure-activity relationship of the catalyst has been elucidated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation In a typical procedure for NiO catalyst synthesis, Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (0.6g) were dissolved into 30mL water-ethanol (volume ratio, 1:1) solvent to form a homogeneous solution. 0.1g PEG or PVP template was added into the above solution, and then the hexamethylenetetramine (HMTA) solution (0.5mol/L) was added dropwise into it until the pH is around 9. Afterwards, the mixture was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, which was heated to 110°C and kept at the same temperature for 15h. A green solid powder was obtained via filtrating and rinsing with water and ethanol until a total dissolved solid (TDS) less than 10ppm. The synthesized sample was dried in an oven controlled at 80°C for 12h, and followed by calcination in a muffle oven heated to 550°C via a ramp of 1°Cmin−1 and maintained at the same temperature for 4h in air atmosphere to get the final catalysts. According to the template used in the preparation, the final catalysts are named NiO-PEG or NiO-PVP. NiO-PEG, the best catalyst in this study, was also calcined at 650, 750, 850°C for 4h to investigate its thermal stability, which was denoted by NiO-PEG-650, NiO-PEG-750 and NiO-PEG-850, respectively, according to the calcination temperature. For comparison purpose, a polycrystalline NiO powder catalyst was prepared by direct thermal decomposition of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O in a muffle oven at 550°C for 4h in air atmosphere, which was named NiO-Cal. 2.2 Activity evaluation The catalysts have been evaluated for CH4 total oxidation with a U-shaped quartz tube (ID=6mm) fixed-bed reactor. The volume composition of the reactant feed is 1% CH4, 22% O2 and balanced by high purity N2, with a total flow rate of 30mLmin−1. Usually, 100mg of catalyst with an average size of 0.3-0.4mm was adopted for activity test, resulting in WHSV of 18, 000mLg−1 h−1. A K-type thermocouple was used to monitor the reaction temperatures, with its head point touching the catalyst bed for accurate measurement. To obtain the light-off curves of the catalysts, all data have been achieved by improving the temperatures. The left reactants and formed products have been analyzed on-line on a GC9310 gas chromatograph equipped with a TDX-01 column and a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Prior to analysis, the reaction at a certain temperature will be stabilized at least 30min to get steady state reaction data. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The scanning electron microscope (SEM) experiments were carried out on a Hitachi S-4800 field emission scanning electron microscope. The Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM) experiments were performed on a Tecnai™ F30 transmission electron microscope. Nitrogen adsorption/desorption experiments of the catalysts were carried out at 77K on Micromeritics ASAP2020 instrument. The pore size distributions of the catalysts were calculated with Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. The mean pore sizes of the catalysts were achieved from the distribution curves. The specific surface areas of the catalysts were quantified using Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method in the relative pressure range of p/p0 =0.05–0.35. The small angle and wide angle X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a Bruker AXSD8Focus diffractometer instrument operating at 40kV and 30mA, with Cu target Kα irradiation (λ=1.5405Å). Scans were collected in the range of 2θ =0.5–10° to measure the mesoporous structure of the catalysts; and in the range of 2θ =10–80° with a step of 2° min−1 to analyze the bulk phase composition and crystallite size of the critical species. The calculated experimental error for 2θ measurement of the peaks is±0.01°. For good comparison of the results, all of the catalysts were analyzed continuously under the same conditions. Hydrogen temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was performed on FINESORB 3010C instrument. Typically, in a 30mLmin−1 10% H2/Ar reductant gas mixture flow, 20mg of catalyst was adopted for the test. Before the experiment, the catalyst was pre-treated in a high purity Ar flow for 30min at 200°C to clean any surface impurities. Afterwards, it was then heated in a 30mLmin−1 10% H2/Ar flow from room temperature to 800°C with a ramping rate of 10°Cmin−1. A TCD was used to measure the H2 uptake amount. For quantification purpose, a CuO (99.99%) standard sample was used to calibrate the system. Oxygen temperature programmed desorption (O2-TPD) was carried out on Micromeritics ASAP2920 instrument. Typically, 50mg of sample was placed in a quartz reactor, pretreated in a 30mLmin−1 ultra-high purity (UHP) He flow at 200°C for 2h, then saturated in a 30mLmin−1 3% O2 (He balance) flow at 50°C for 1h. Afterwards, the catalyst was purged with a 30mLmin−1 UHP He flow for 30min to desorb physically adsorbed O2. O2-TPD was then carried out from 50 to 800°C with a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1 in a 30mLmin−1 UHP He flow. A TCD was used to monitor the desorbed oxygen species. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) tests were performed on a PerkinElmer PHI1600 system using a single Mg Kα X-ray source operating at 300W and 15kV. The spectra of the catalysts were achieved at room temperature in an ultrahigh vacuum. The binding energies were calibrated by using the C 1 s peak of a standard graphite sample at 284.5eV as a reference. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The morphology of the catalysts measured with SEM Fig. 1 displays the SEM images of the NiO samples prepared with different methods. It is evident that the NiO catalysts possess varied morphologies. When prepared by hydrothermal method with PEG (Figs. 1a and b) or PVP (Figs. 1c and d) as the templates, the obtained samples, NiO-PEG and NiO-PVP, exhibit three-dimensional nanoflower morphologies, consisting of sheets with a thickness around 15nm in the petals. In addition, the morphology of NiO-PEG is neater than that of NiO-PVP. In contrast, NiO-Cal, the sample obtained by the direct calcination of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, is composed of large triangular prism-like particles with an average grain size around 500nm, as shown in Figs. 1e and f. In brief, by using hydrothermal method with PEG or PVP as the soft templates, NiO nanosheets, which assemble into 3D nanoflower morphology, have been successfully synthesized. 3.2 N2 adsorption/desorption measurement of the catalysts To investigate the porous structure of the catalysts, N2 adsorption/desorption experiments were conducted, with the isotherms and the pore-size distribution profiles illustrated in Fig. 2 . In addition, the BET surface areas, average pore volumes and pore diameters are also listed in Table 1 . The specific surface areas of NiO-PEG, NiO-PVP and NiO-Cal are 82.8, 61.4 and 3.7m2 g−1 in sequence. It is noted here that the surface areas of NiO-PEG and NiO-PVP are not only much higher than that of NiO-Cal in this study, but also higher than that of the NiO samples prepared with precipitation method, which have been formerly reported by us [16]. This strongly demonstrates that with hydrothermal template technique, NiO catalysts with much higher surface areas can be achieved, which is believed to be favorable for the activity of the catalysts. Fig. 2 exhibits the N2 adsorption/desorption results of the NiO catalysts. All the samples exhibit a type IV nitrogen sorption isotherm with one or two capillary condensation steps. While NiO-Cal, the sample prepared by direct calcination of nickel nitrate, displays little nitrogen adsorption/desorption amount, both of NiO-PEG and NiO-PVP show much larger ones, as listed in Table 1. In addition, on the isotherm of NiO-Cal, only one H3-type hysteresis loop is observed, which indicates the presence of only one set of interparticle mesopores with an average size around 32.1nm in its structure. Whereas, on the isotherms of NiO-PEG and NiO-PVP, two sets of hysteresis loops are obviously observed, which indicates the presence of two sets of mesopores in their structure, as also testified by the size distribution profiles in Fig. 2(b). The first set of mesopores with an average pore size around 3nm is attributed to the intraparticle pores, and the second set of mesopores with an average pore size around 25–26nm is attributed to the interparticle pores [29]. Apparently, for the two samples synthesized with hydrothermal template method, there present two set of mesopores with varied average pore sizes, which result in a totally average pore sizes around 14–15nm. It is believed that the presence of pores with different sizes is favorable for the diffusion of the reactants and their effective contact with the active sites [30,31], thus improving their activity toward CH4 deep oxidation. 3.3 XRD analysis of the catalysts To further confirm the textural information achieved by N2 adsorption/desorption, XRD was used to analyze the phase composition and pore structure of the NiO catalysts prepared with different methods, with the patterns shown in Fig. 3 . First, small-angle XRD was employed to confirm the formation of mesopores in the structure of NiO-PEG and NiO-PVP catalysts. As shown in Fig. 3a, a sharp diffraction peak at around 0.9° was observed for the two samples prepared by hydrothermal template method, but not for NiO-Cal sample, which is indexed to the (211) reflection in the cubic Ia3d space group [32]. Apparently, the presence of this small angle diffraction peak substantiates strongly the formation of highly ordered mesoporous structure in NiO-PEG and NiO-PVP catalysts [33], which is well consistent with the N2 adsorption/desorption results. The wide-angle XRD patterns of the NiO catalysts are shown in Fig. 3b. All the NiO samples show the diffraction peaks at 37.2°, 43.3°, 62.9°, 75.4° and 79.4°, corresponding to the diffraction of (111), (200), (220), (311) and (222) facets of cubic NiO (JCPDS PDF# 47-1049), respectively. To evaluate the crystallinity of the catalysts, the crystalline sizes of all the NiO catalysts have been calculated from the peak at 43.3° of (200) diffraction plane by using the Scherrer equation, as shown in Table 1. The crystallite sizes of the samples follow the sequence of NiO-PEG < NiO-PVP < NiO-Cal, which is well consistent with the specific surface area results. It is particularly mentioned that the NiO-PEG sample, the best catalyst in this study, has the smallest crystallite size and the highest surface area. 3.4 HR-TEM images of the catalysts Fig. 4 shows the TEM and HR-TEM images of the NiO samples prepared with different methods. Obviously, mesoporous structure is observed for NiO-PEG and NiO-PVP, as illustrated in Figs. 4a and c, which is in agreement with N2 adsorption/desorption and small angle XRD results. However, Figs. 4e and f indicate the lack of porous structure in NiO-Cal sample, which display only the assembling of irregular particles. Figs. 4b, d and f display the HR-TEM images of the NiO samples. The preferentially exposed (200) facets are observed for all the NiO samples with different morphologies, which has clear lattice fringes with a spacing around 0.21nm, testifying the exposed facets are not the reason accounting for their activity difference [21,22]. 3.5 Activity tests for CH4 deep oxidation The activity of the catalysts was evaluated for CH4 deep oxidation, with the results shown in Fig. 5 and Table 2 . It is commonly accepted that alumina-supported Pd is the most active catalyst for CH4 deep oxidation [1], therefore, an 1wt.% Pd/Al2O3 catalyst was also prepared and tested under the same condition for comparison purpose. As shown in Fig. 5a, among all the NiO catalysts, NiO-PEG shows the highest overall activity, on which the temperatures corresponding to 10%, 50% and 100% CH4 conversion (T 10, T 50 and T 100) are around 320, 370 and 440°C. Most importantly, the overall activity of NiO-PEG is almost identical to that of 1wt.% Pd/Al2O3, as demonstrated by their nearly overlapped conversion versus temperature curves. In contrast, while the overall activity of NiO-PVP is slightly lower than that of NiO-PEG, NiO-Cal shows the lowest catalytic activity among all the catalysts, as testified by its T 10, T 50 and T 100 around 385, 450 and 550°C. In summary, the overall activity of the catalysts follows the sequence of 1wt.% Pd/Al2O3 ≈NiO-PEG > NiO-PVP >> NiO-Cal, which indicates that the NiO catalysts prepared with hydrothermal template method are more active for the target reaction. To probe the inherent activity of the catalysts, the Arrhenius plots of all the samples have been obtained and displayed in Fig. 5b. For easy comparison, the apparent activation energies and methane conversion rates at 325°C are also calculated with the formula based on the Arrhenius plots of all the catalysts (Table 2). To eliminate any diffusion influence, the CH4 conversion rates adopted to achieve the Arrhenius plots have been collected under differential conditions by controlling the CH4 conversions not above 20%. It is apparent that over unit amount of catalyst, the activity follows the order of 1wt.% Pd/Al2O3 ≈NiO-PEG > NiO-PVP >> NiO-Cal, proving NiO-PEG possesses close activity to 1wt.% Pd/Al2O3. It is easy to find that the larger the surface area, the higher the overall activity of a NiO catalyst. Therefore, to gain deeper understanding on the factors influencing the activity, R w and R s, the differential rates normalized by catalyst weights and surface areas, are plotted against the surface areas of the catalysts, and displayed in Fig. 6 . It is interesting to find that all the NiO catalysts prepared by different methods and with varied morphologies have nearly the same R s, demonstrating that they possess surface active sites with the same properties. This is well consistent with the HR-TEM results to demonstrate that they have the same exposed (200) facets (Fig. 4). Whereas, a proportional linear relationship between R w and the surface areas can be observed, indicating the rates normalized by the catalysts weight increase with increasing the surface areas. As previous work has substantiated that CH4 deep oxidation is diffusion controlled rather than reaction controlled, especially at high CH4 conversions [17,18]. Therefore, it is apparent that the high surface areas of NiO-PEG and NiO-PVP, the samples prepared by hydrothermal template method, is one of the predominant reasons accounting for their significantly improved overall activity. 3.6 H2-TPR analysis on the redox properties In order to understand the reasons influencing the activity of the NiO samples, H2-TPR was adopted to investigate their redox properties. As shown in Fig. 7 , a major reduction peak was evidently observed for all the samples in the temperature range of 250–500°C, which is attributed to the reduction of NiO into metallic Ni [21,22]. For NiO-PEG, NiO-PVP and NiO-Cal samples, this peak was centered at 301, 320 and 448°C, respectively. Generally, for individual metal oxides, such as NiO in this study, if a sample has a higher surface area, its crystallite size is smaller (see Table 1) and crystallinity is lower. As a result, its lattice oxygen will be more facile and easier to be reduced. The different lattice oxygen mobility observed here is thus essentially related to the different surface area of the NiO samples. Apparently, the reducibility of the oxygen species in the samples is well consistent with their oxidation activity sequence, proving the lattice oxygen mobility is another reason affecting the activity of the catalysts. As a p-type semiconductor, Ni2+ vacancies generally take place in the crystal matrix of NiO [34]. To keep electric neutrality and charge balance, the two neighboring Ni2+ cations will lose an extra electron to form two Ni3+ cations [35]. In theory, if all the Ni species are present as Ni2+ cations in the crystal lattice, the calculated H2 uptake amount and H/Ni atomic ratio should be 13.38mmolg−1 and 2/1, respectively [22]. However, the quantification results in Table 3 demonstrate that both the H2 uptake amount and the H/Ni atomic ratios are higher than the theoretical ones, verifying the formation of Ni3+ cations in the bulk. Moreover, the major reduction peak of the NiO samples is not symmetric, which implies the overlapped reduction of both Ni3+ and Ni2+ cations. Therefore, the major peak of each sample was deconvoluted into two peaks, as shown in Fig. 7. The first shoulder peak is ascribed to the reduction of Ni3+ to Ni2+, while the second major peak is assigned to the reduction of Ni2+ to Ni0 [21,22]. Based on this, the Ni3+/Ni2+ atomic ratios of the catalysts are quantified. As shown in Table 3, NiO-PEG, the best catalyst, possesses the least amount of Ni3+ cations. However, NiO-Cal, the worst catalyst, possesses the largest amount of Ni3+ cations. It is evident that the formation of Ni3+ due to the presence of Ni2+ vacancies are harmful for the CH4 deep oxidation activity, which is in agreement with our former work [16]. 3.7 O2-TPD and XPS analysis on the oxygen property and surface composition Fig. 8 shows the O2-TPD profiles of the NiO samples prepared by different methods. Three categories of oxygen desorption peaks are detected in all the catalysts. The peak below 220°C denoted as α oxygen is ascribed to the oxygen species adsorbed chemically on the surface of NiO [36,37]. The peaks between 220 and 470°C denoted as β oxygen are attributed to be non-stoichiometric oxygen species [38], which is most probably the oxygen species neighboring the Ni2+ vacancy sites [16]. The peak above 470°C denoted as γ oxygen is assigned to the desorption of the lattice oxygen of NiO [34]. For better understanding, all the three categories of oxygen species have been integrated and normalized by catalyst weight. As shown in Table 4 , the amount of γ oxygen species for each NiO catalyst is nearly the same, while both of the amounts of α and β oxygen species followed the order of NiO-PEG > NiO-PVP > NiO-Cal. Compared with the activity results, it is obvious that the amount of α and β oxygen species is crucial for CH4 deep oxidation [39]. XPS was used to investigate the surface properties of the NiO samples, with the spectra shown in Fig. 9 and the quantified results listed in Table 4. As shown in Fig. 9a, three Ni 2p 3/2 peaks with different binding energies are observed for each sample. According to former publications, the main peak at around 854eV and the broad satellite peak centered at around 861eV can be assigned to surface Ni2+ species in NiO [40,41], while the shoulder peak at around 856eV can be attributed to surface Ni3+ species due to the presence of Ni2+ vacancies in NiO crystal lattices [41,42], which is also evidenced by its close binding energy to that of the Ni3+ in Ni2O3 [43] and NiOOH [44]. To quantify the surface Ni3+/Ni2+ molar ratios (Table 4), the 856 and 854eV peaks are deconvoluted and integrated. Afterwards, the surface Ni3+/Ni2+ ratios are calculated by dividing the integrated area of Ni3+ with that of Ni2+ [37]. Apparently, the surface Ni3+/Ni2+ ratio of the catalysts follows the order of NiO-PEG < NiO-PVP < NiO-Cal, which is in agreement with the bulk sequence detected by H2-TPR. To figure out the effects of surface Ni3+ amount on the activity of the catalysts, R w, the differential rates normalized by catalyst weights are plotted against the surface Ni3+/Ni2+ ratio of the catalysts. As shown in Fig. 10 , the rate is inverse proportional to the surface Ni3+/Ni2+ ratio, testifying again that the presence of too much surface Ni3+ species is detrimental to the activity of the catalysts. Fig. 9b displays the O 1 s signals of the NiO samples. The peak around 528eV is assigned to surface lattice oxygen (Olatt), while the other peak around 530eV is typical for the loosely bonded surface oxygen species (Oads) [21]. The Oads/Olatt molar ratios for all the samples were quantified, which follow the sequence of NiO-PEG > NiO-PVP > NiO-Cal (Table 4), in agreement with the O2-TPD results. Furthermore, the NiO-PEG sample with the largest surface area has the highest Oads/Olatt ratio, indicating that high surface area is beneficial to the formation of more facile and reactive oxygen species [22]. In summary, H2-TPR, O2-TPD and XPS results confirm that more mobile active oxygen species has been formed on the two samples prepared with hydrothermal template method, which is believed to be a result from their mesoporous structure and high surface areas, and could be another major reason accounting for their much improved activity for CH4 deep oxidation. 3.8 Effect of calcination temperature on the NiO-PEG catalyst To investigate the thermal stability of NiO-PEG, the most active catalyst in this study, it was subjected to calcination at higher temperatures and evaluated for CH4 deep oxidation, with the results exhibited in Fig. 11 . Apparently, the overall activity drops with the increase of the calcination temperature. However, even if the catalyst is calcined at 850°C, its activity is still higher than that of NiO-Cal. To explore the influence of calcination temperatures on the structure and morphology of the catalyst, NiO-PEG-850, the catalyst calcined at 850°C was subjected to SEM measurements. As shown in Figs. 12 a and b, the initial sheets of NiO-PEG (Fig. 1) can still be observed but some collapsing and aggregation of the flower petals are observed due to the high temperature impact. As a result, the original nanoflower morphology disappeared. N2 adsorption/desorption experiments were also performed to study the textural change of NiO-PEG catalyst calcined at different temperatures shown in Fig. S1. As listed in Table 5 , after increasing the calcination temperature from 550 to 850°C, the surface areas and pore volumes of the catalyst monotonically decrease from 82.8 to 14.5m2 g−1 and 0.30 to 0.15cm3 g−1, respectively. In contrast, the corresponding average pore diameters gradually increase from 14.1 to 73.8 nm as expected. Interestingly, Fig. S1 shows that the two original slopes and H3-type hysteresis loops on the nitrogen sorption isotherm of NiO-PEG still exist with bimodal pore size distribution for NiO-PEG-650. However, the slope and hysteresis loop corresponding to the intraparticle mesopores vanishes in NiO-PEG-750 and NiO-PEG-850 catalysts, proving too high temperature can damage those intraparticle pores in the bulk structure. Fig. S2 illustrated the XRD patterns of NiO-PEG samples calcined at different temperatures. It is easily found that all the samples show more intensive diffraction peaks, due to the better crystallization of the sample at higher temperatures. The crystallite size change of the samples listed in Table 5 also proves this. Fig. S3 shows the H2-TPR profiles of NiO-PEG calcined at different temperatures. By increasing the calcination temperature, the major reduction peak shifts to higher temperature gradually, indicating the reducibility of the oxygen species is weakened due to better crystallization. Table 6 summarizes the hydrogen consumption amount and H/Ni molar ratios of the NiO samples calcined at different temperatures. Obviously, the total hydrogen consumption amount and H/Ni molar ratio decrease slightly by increasing the calcination temperature. In other words, the amounts of Ni3+ decrease with increasing the calcination temperature, as testified by the decrease of the Ni3+/Ni2+ molar ratios. This is well consistent with the fact that the NiO-PEG calcined at higher temperatures is better crystallized, thus having less Ni2+ vacancies in the bulk structure. 3.9 Stability and water resistance measurements of the NiO-PEG catalyst For application purposes, the stability in the presence or absence of water vapour is a critical issue of a catalyst for CH4 deep oxidation. Hence, NiO-PEG, the most active catalyst in this work, was evaluated at 410°C for 60h with or without 5% water vapour at a WHSV of 18, 000mLg−1 h−1. As shown in Fig. 13 b, there is only a negligible decrease for CH4 conversion after the addition of 5% water vapour. Moreover, no evident decline for CH4 conversion can be observed during the 60 h’s stability tests, either with or without water vapour, proving that the catalyst is stable and also resistant to deactivation by water vapour. To explore the structure stability of the catalyst, the NiO-PEG sample after the activity evaluation and 60 h’s stability tests were also measured by N2 adsorption/desorption shown in Fig. S4. As shown in Table S1, after activity evaluation, the surface area of NiO-PEG decreases from 82.8 to 55.9m2 g−1. After 60 h’s stability test, its surface area drops to 43.7m2 g−1. This indicates that the mesoporous structure of NiO-PEG may not be very stable, but the surface area is still much higher than that of NiO-Cal (3.7m2 g−1). It is noted here that the pore volume of the catalyst decreases slightly and the pore size increases a little bit. In addition, Fig. S4 testifies that the initial intraparticle and interparticle mesopores are still present in the structure of NiO-PEG after activity evaluation and stability test. As shown in Fig. S5(a), in the small-angle XRD patterns of the NiO-PEG catalyst after activity evaluation and stability test, the distinguished peak at around 0.9°, which is typical of the ordered mesoporous NiO, can still be observed. Fig. S5(b) shows that both of the used samples show the same diffraction characteristics to the fresh one. Compared with the fresh catalyst, the crystallite sizes of the used NiO-PEG samples in Table S1 shows the growth of the crystallite sizes is insignificant. In summary, NiO-PEG is not only active, but also stable for CH4 deep oxidation either in the presence or in the absence of water vapour. Moreover, its bulk structure possesses certain physical stability. Considering its competitive activity to 1wt.% Pd/Al2O3, if its structure stability can be further improved, a catalyst with potential industrial application without using noble metals could be developed for CH4 deep oxidation. 4 Conclusions In this study, with the objective to achieve improved NiO catalysts for CH4 deep oxidation, which have the potential to replace noble metal oxide catalysts, hydrothermal method with PEG and PVP as soft templates has been used to prepare NiO catalysts with mesoporous structure and much improved surface areas. (1) N2 adsorption/desorption, XRD and TEM analysis have revealed that both NiO-PEG and NiO-PVP possess a large amount of intraparticle and interparticle mesopores with different sizes in comparison with NiO catalysts prepared with direct calcination and precipitation methods, thus resulting in catalysts with much higher surface areas. (2) H2-TPR, O2-TPD and XPS results have proved that a larger quantity of more mobile active oxygen species have been formed in these two catalysts, which is believed to be the consequence of the formation of mesoporous structure and high surface area. (3) The high surface area and mesoporous structure are favorable for the diffusion and contacting of the reactants with the active sites; and the formation of more mobile oxygen species is beneficial to the activating and oxidizing of the CH4 molecules. These are believed to be the major factors improving the activity of the catalysts for CH4 deep oxidation. Furthermore, on NiO catalysts, it is revealed that the CH4 deep oxidation reaction is most possibly diffusion controlled. (4) The formation of too much Ni3+ cations, which is induced by the Ni2+ vacancies present in the NiO crystal matrix, is harmful to the activity. (5) With the optimal tuning of all the factors, NiO-PEG displays the highest activity to the target reaction, which is even rival to 1wt.% Pd/Al2O3 catalyst. In addition, this catalyst exhibits excellent reaction stability in the presence or absence of water vapour, and certain physical and thermal stability for the reaction. Indeed, the information provided in this work may give people some new thoughts to develop catalysts without using noble metals for air emission control reactions. coredata.dc:description: Mesoporous NiO nano-sheet catalysts have been successfully synthesized by hydrothermal method with polyethylene glycol (NiO-PEG) and polyvinyl pyrrolidone (NiO-PVP) as soft templates. Compared with NiO catalysts prepared with direct calcination and precipitation methods, both NiO-PEG and NiO-PVP possess a large amount of intraparticle and interparticle mesopores with different sizes, thus resulting in catalysts with much higher surface areas. As a consequence, a larger quantity of more mobile active oxygen species have been formed in these two catalysts. It is believed that the mesoporous structure, high surface area and the presence of more mobile oxygen species are the major factors improving the activity of the catalysts for CH4 deep oxidation. The formation of too much Ni3+ cations, which is induced by the Ni2+ vacancies present in the NiO crystal matrix, is harmful to the activity. With the optimal tuning of the above factors, NiO-PEG displays the highest activity to the target reaction, which is even rival to 1wt.% Pd/Al2O3 catalyst. In addition, this catalyst exhibits excellent reaction stability in the presence or absence of water vapour, and certain physical and thermal stability for the reaction. Indeed, the information provided in this work may give people some inspiration to develop catalysts without using noble metals for air emission control reactions.
coredata.dc:title: Mesoporous high surface area NiO synthesized with soft templates: Remarkable for catalytic CH4 deep oxidation
